Natural Gas: The Lifeline of Modern Energy

SISTRANGAS
regulatory
gas flows
Author

Eduardo Prud’homme

Published

March 28, 2025

On this page

  • The Backbone of Energy: Pipeline Networks
  • From Transmission to Consumption
  • Why Pipelines Matter
  • Ensuring Safe and Efficient Operations
  • The Need for Transparency and Accountability
  • Upcoming: Mexico's Gas Pipeline Insights
    • Inside Gas Processing: Adding Value to Raw Resources

Natural gas is a vital energy source for millions of homes and businesses worldwide. As a relatively clean and efficient fuel, it powers electricity generation, heats homes, maintains essential services, and fuels industries.

In 2022, U.S. power generators produced about 4,243 million megawatt-hours (MWh) of electricity, with nearly 40% coming from natural gas. Similarly, in Mexico, gas-based technologies accounted for almost half of the country's 90,000 MW of installed power capacity in 2021. Across North America and beyond, vast networks of natural gas pipelines ensure this crucial resource flows seamlessly from production fields to end users.

The Backbone of Energy: Pipeline Networks

The natural gas pipeline system is an intricate web of steel pipes—ranging from a few centimeters to several meters in diameter—that transports gas from production sites to distribution hubs. These pipelines link supply sources—such as gas wells, processing plants, international interconnections, and storage facilities—to major consumption centers via city gates, where local distribution begins.

  • The U.S. boasts the world's most extensive pipeline network, spanning over 340,000 kilometers.

  • Canada follows with nearly 61,000 km of pipelines.

  • Mexico has a significant system exceeding 17,000 km.

Together, North America holds about 40% of the world's gas transmission pipelines, ensuring reliable energy delivery across the continent.

From Transmission to Consumption

Gas transmission lines typically deliver fuel to city gates, where local distribution networks take over, supplying residential, commercial, and industrial customers. While these distribution systems directly serve end users, the real market dynamics—pricing, capacity allocation, and supply balancing—are driven by transmission pipelines.

Key hubs and interconnections maintain system equilibrium, ensuring gas flows efficiently across regions and over time.

Why Pipelines Matter

Natural gas pipelines are the unsung heroes of modern life. In Mexico, electricity generation without natural gas would fall short of meeting demand. Beyond power, gas fuels:

  • Heating & cooking in homes

  • Industrial production of glass, steel, cement, ceramics, and petrochemicals

  • Alternative fuel for vehicles

The direct link between gas availability and economic prosperity is undeniable. That's why investing in skilled labor, technology, and transparent operations is crucial for ensuring affordable, secure, and uninterrupted gas supply.

Ensuring Safe and Efficient Operations

A well-functioning pipeline system requires:

  • Constant monitoring (leak detection, pressure checks, flow control)

  • Sophisticated technology to manage complex injection and withdrawal points

  • Effective commercial coordination to prevent imbalances, congestion, or underutilization

In North America, industry practices and regulations have shaped how market players interact. The North American Energy Standards Board (NAESB) plays a key role by defining protocols for capacity management and gas scheduling. Its daily gas nomination cycle—widely adopted in the U.S. and Canada—ensures seamless coordination across interconnected supply chains.

The Need for Transparency and Accountability

Pipelines are only as reliable as their operators. Lack of competition, restricted open access, or opaque contracts can disrupt affordability and supply stability—common challenges in transitioning gas markets like Mexico's.

To secure a stable energy future, the industry must prioritize:
✅ Safety
✅ Efficiency
✅ Transparency

Natural gas will remain a primary energy source for decades. Public awareness, data accessibility, and regulatory progress are essential to fostering a modern, responsible gas industry for future generations.

Upcoming: Mexico's Gas Pipeline Insights

Stay tuned as we unveil an in-depth report on Mexico's natural gas transportation network. We'll explore:
🔹 Key injection points into the SISTRANGAS (Integrated National Transport and Storage System)
🔹 Major private pipelines and their roles
🔹 Gas processing plants, like the Burgos Gas Processing Complex—a critical hub supplying dry gas into SISTRANGAS

Inside Gas Processing: Adding Value to Raw Resources

Processing plants purify natural gas, removing impurities (water, CO₂, sulfur) and separating hydrocarbons into marketable products like:

  • Dry natural gas

  • Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG)

  • Natural Gas Liquids (NGLs)

  • Naphtha

The Burgos Complex, operated by PEMEX, processes 1.2 billion cubic feet per day of wet gas, delivering vital products into Mexico's energy grid.

Coming next: Data-driven insights on gas flows, nominations, and market trends.

(Source: CENAGAS electronic bulletin. Illustrated data reflects scheduled gas movements under NAESB protocols.)

Why follow this series?
Because understanding energy infrastructure means understanding energy security, competitiveness, and open access—issues that impact us all.
